did.unittitle: Marshall L. Cook and William R. Cook papers 1880-1945
did.abstract: Editor and publisher, with his brother, William Randolph Cook, of the Hastings Banner in Hastings, Michigan. Correspondence, 1893-1941, relating to operations of their paper and other business enterprises, including material concerning Republican politics, the temperance movement, their activities and interest in the Rotary Club, the Salvation Army, and the Young Men's Christian Association.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was the gift of Richard M. Cook (donor no. 3240) and came to the library in multiple accessions.

accruals.p: No further additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Marshall L. Cook and William R. Cook papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Marshall L. Cook was born August 12, 1858 in Prairieville Township, Barry County, Michigan. After attending Albion College, he returned to Hastings, Michigan where he purchased an interest in the Hastings Banner newspaper around 1880. In 1889, his brother William R. Cook was able to buy out one of the newspapers owners and from that time the two brothers operated the newspaper together.

William R. Cook was born January 28, 1866. He attended the University of Michigan for two years, then returned to Hastings where he intended to study law. For reasons of health, he was forced to abandon these plans and instead purchased an interest in the local newspaper and printing business which he operated with his brother.

The two brothers were active in civic, professional, and political affairs. William R. Cook was long-time treasurer of the Michigan Press Association and secretary of the Hastings Rotary Club. Marshall L. Cook was president of the Michigan Republican Editors Association.

scopecontent.p: The collection has been arranged into three series: Correspondence; Hasting Rotary Club; and Miscellaneous. The correspondence has been arranged chronologically with separate folders when needed for specific kinds of activities of the two brothers: political, business, church activities, and other professional responsibilities.

odd.p: (include letters from Shirley Smith describing his trip through Europe, June -- August)
(include letters concerning local post office patronage and service)

Political articles and a speech, election campaign 1900

odd.p: (include articles on the Grange as an organization and dealing with Trusts)
(include copies of newspapers and a Hastings publication; also student notebook, 1880 of Marshall Cook, while attending Albion College)

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The library also has the records of the Cook Brothers Printing Company of Hastings, Michigan.
